qas.question: How many techniques are available because of ISO 12232:2006?
What techniques did CIPA DC-004 provide?

answers.text: two new techniques allowing for measurement of JPEG output files

qas.question: What factors affect the exposure index rating?

answers.text: the sensor sensitivity, the sensor noise, and the appearance of the resulting image

qas.question: What does the standard of ISO 12232:2006 specify?

answers.text: the measurement of light sensitivity of the entire digital camera system and not of individual components

qas.question: In what year did Kodak start using a different way of characterizing two sensors?
How many JPEG techniques were introduced in 1998?

plausible_answers.text: sensor sensitivity, the sensor noise, and the appearance of the resulting image

qas.question: What are the three techniques that affect ISO?
How many techniques depend on sensor sensitivity?
When did Kodak stop using variations of sensitivity?

context: The ISO standard ISO 12232:2006 gives digital still camera manufacturers a choice of <a0_0><b8_0>five<b8_0/><a0_0/> different techniques for determining the exposure index rating at each sensitivity setting provided by a particular camera model. <b6_0>Three<b6_0/> of the techniques in ISO 12232:2006 are carried over from the <b5_0>1998<b5_0/> version of the standard, while <a1_0>two new techniques allowing for measurement of JPEG output files<a1_0/> are introduced from CIPA DC-004. Depending on the technique selected, the exposure index rating can depend on <a2_0>the <b7_0>sensor sensitivity, the sensor noise, and the appearance of the resulting image<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The standard specifies <a3_0>the measurement of light sensitivity of the entire digital camera system and not of individual components<a3_0/> such as digital sensors, although Kodak has reported using a variation to characterize the sensitivity of two of their sensors in <a4_0><b9_0>2001<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
